awd_titl_txt: GOALI:  An Integrated Framework for Stiction Detection and Compensation in Control Loops
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT

PI: Raghunatha Rengasamy and Randy Miller 
Institution:  Clarkson University
Proposal Number: 0553992
Title: An Integrated Framework for Stiction Detection and Compensation in Control Loops

Project Summary

This NSF GOALI project is a joint effort between Clarkson University and Honeywell, USA for the development and implementation of controller performance monitoring techniques.  The last decade has seen the emergence and commercialization of on-line control loop performance-monitoring techniques.  The primary objectives of any performance-monitoring tool can be categorized as: (i) detection of performance degradation, (ii) diagnosis of the cause for performance degradation, and (iii) corrective action.  While the first objective has been addressed comprehensively in the literature, work on the other two objectives is lacking.  In this project, the focus will be on oscillation diagnosis, stiction detection, and stiction compensation.  Quantitative and qualitative techniques will be explored for solving these problems.  Through industrial collaboration with Honeywell, all the techniques that are developed will be extensively validated on one million industrial control loops.

Intellectual Merit: 

Shape-based and model-based algorithms will be developed for stiction diagnosis. The scalability issues in the deployment of these algorithms will be studied through benchmarking on a million industrial control loop dataset. The development of both model-free and model-based stiction-compensation algorithms are envisaged.   Preliminary results suggest that highly optimal compensation signals can be designed with benign valve movements for stiction compensation. 

Broader Impact: 

This work will generate tools that can be leveraged by the US process industries to maintain their competitive edge.  Results arising out of the project will provide Honeywell with a performance assessment tool that can be benchmarked on a large database of loop data and subsequently implemented on a wide variety of control loops. It has been estimated that detection and diagnosis of control loop degradation alone could reduce energy cost of the overall process industry by 1% which could amount to as much as $300 million per year.  This could be a driving force for other control vendors to embrace and develop their own controller performance monitoring tools.  The dissemination activities include: publication in archival journals, presentation at conferences targeted at academicians and industry participants, and inclusion of material in a book on fault diagnosis that the PI is co-authoring.  A laboratory experiment will be upgraded at Clarkson University and will be used to teach undergraduate students the concept of Controller Performance Assessment.  The PI will work closely with Clarkson's Pipeline of Education Program to recruit talented underrepresented students from universities with which Clarkson has established articulation agreements and/or memorandums of understanding.

por.por_cntn:
GOALI: An Integrated Framework for Stiction Detection and Compensation in Control Loops

Control loops form the back-bone in any industrial facility. The control loops are tasked with responsibilities related to keeping the industrial processes safe, optimal and efficient. Whenever control loops malfunction, the results are wastage of resources and/or process variable excursions beyond control limits. The reasons that a control loop could malfunction are many but the most significant of them are related to poor controller tuning and stiction (static friction) in control valves.  Control loop malfunctions affect the consumers directly in terms of increased prices and lower quality final products. The magnitude of this problem can be understood from the estimate that if detection and diagnosis of control loop degradation could reduce energy cost of the overall process industry by just 1% - this would amount to as much as $ 300 million per year. In response to this challenge, work in academia has focused on the development of tools and methods that address this problem. However, translating such tools to industrial practice requires that academic assumptions be questioned, techniques be modified to suit the industry needs, and work be undertaken to see these techniques deployed in operating control loops. This project is on the development and implementation of controller performance monitoring techniques in industrial setting – in essence, translating academic approaches to practice.

The broad objectives of this work were: (i) Develop data-based control performance assessment techniques for univariate and multivariate systems, (ii) Develop data-based control performance diagnostics for univariate and multivariate systems, and (iii) Develop mitigation approaches for improving control loop performance. Work on these objectives has resulted in the following key developments: (i) Demonstration of model based approaches for stiction detection – a shift from qualitative stiction diagnosis techniques that were popular before this project work was undertaken, (ii) Demonstration that stiction compensation is possible without excessive valve movements, and (iii) Demonstration that it is possible to assess controller performance without model information. Based on the project work, a patent for a novel stiction compensation method was awarded. This compensation method has the potential of being implemented in thousands of control loops and several practitioners are working on improving this idea even further for industrial practice. The control loop diagnosis tool developed through this project has been bench-marked on many industrial control loops and a software product based on this work is being evaluated. Other than the technological contributions, in terms of manpower development, several graduate students were trained in this area and undergraduate students were provided research experience. The results of this work have been disseminated through several avenues such as presentations and publications in peer-reviewed conferences, publications in peer-reviewed journals, and outreach to companies.

In summary, work on this project has resulted in control loop monitoring techniques becoming more accessible to industrial practice. Wide-spread implementation of these techniques could potentially save millions of dollars by reducing wastage and improving product quality in industrial processes.
